Write code to meet a certain goal, then trade your code with someone else and act out each other's programs! Test your algorithmic thinking and your acting skills all at once! FIREHOSE: Eat our food and take our classes until stupid late!

You all know that the square root of negative 1 is i. But what if there are more square roots of negative 1? Or nonzero square roots of zero? Spoiler: Calculus happens! Come learn some crazy imaginary math. FIREHOSE: Eat our food and take our classes until stupid late!

column4: FIREHOSE Relativity with Relatively few Paradoxes
column6: You might think special and general relativity is paradoxical. It's not if you look at it the right way, and I'll tell you why. On the way, we'll learn some of the physics of moving really fast. FIREHOSE: Eat our food and take our classes until stupid late!

Think math is boring? Never seen math without numbers? Wonder what mathematicians do all day? The third question is easy: they turn coffee into theorems. Come make the answer to the first two questions no! FIREHOSE: Eat our food and take our classes until stupid late!

column5: New House, House 6, First Floor Lounge
column6: After a night of partying, come join the MIT Black Students' Union. M.I.T B.S.U. and have some Chicken and Waffles while playing some board games.

column4: FIREHOSE More Rigorous Chemistry than you're used to
column6: Why does P.V equal nRT? How can we understand vapor pressure, chemical reactivity, stability of molecules, strengths of intermolecular forces, and what standard reduction potential actually is? Let's use physics to understand all of this! FIREHOSE: Eat our food and take our classes until stupid late!

Worried about getting enough fruits and vegetables once you go off to college? Learn to make bacon-wrapped asparagus and delicious banana bread _that's totally healthy, right? Then we'll share with the rest of FIREHOSE! FIREHOSE: Eat our food and take our classes until stupid late!

column4: FIREHOSE Spaces and homologies and fibrations, oh my!
column6: It's been said that a topologist is someone who can't tell the difference between a doughnut and a coffee cup. Come learn what we can distinguish, and why algebraic topology is awesome! FIREHOSE: Eat our food and take our classes until stupid late!

An infinite number of monkeys need to simultaneously guess the color hat they're wearing. With clever planning beforehand, each monkey can do so almost surely. How? Axiom of Choice! Also covered: the Banach-Tarski Paradox! FIREHOSE: Eat our food and take our classes until stupid late!

column4: FIREHOSE How to sound like you know what you're talking about
column6: I know exactly what I'm talking about. So will you, after leaving this class. By the time you leave, you'll be an expert on being an expert. FIREHOSE: Eat our food and take our classes until stupid late!
Morning bridge loop, a popular route for runners, led by McCormick residents for the first hour. Breakfast available starting at 8:30am.
Looking for breakfast or a bedtime snack? Craving delicious smoothies and waffles? Not enough bacon in your diet? The friendly residents of New House will be serving up breakfast, so come get some!

Kick your day off right with a breakfast meal made to order by our house chef, Karen. Eggs, pancakes, french toast, bacon strips, sausage, fresh fruit, and much more. Don't forget to try the ZBT Classic, a Mc ZBT. Call Rick for Rides 617-232-3257. Remember this event occurs daily!
Stayed up all night? Come fuel up for an exciting day the right way: with a scrumptious assortment of pancakes! Make them your own with rainbow-colored batter!

column4: Course 12 Reception for Students and Parents
column6: Please join us to meet informally with some of the faculty in Course 12: Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences. Find out the breadth of what we have to offer undergraduates. Light breakfast fare will be provided.

Random Hall, it's a quiet village. Every day like the one before. Random Hall, full of little people, waking up to make PANCAKES?! Dig into blueberry chocolate chip spicy cinnamon pancakes while singing along to your favorite Disney songs!

Today, around 100 MIT classes will open their doors to prefrosh attending CPW. Pick up the list sorted by date, time and subject at CPW Check-in. Before sitting in on a class that is not on the list, you must receive permission from the department in advance, some classes will be holding exams or do not have space to accommodate visitors.

column4: CPW Check in and Help Desk
column5: Student Center, 2nd Floor, La Sala de Puerto Rico

column6: Prefrosh, parents and families, please join key MIT Staff for an informal chat and a cup of coffee, tea or juice to start your day! Representatives from MIT Mental Health and Counseling, Student Support Services, Student Outreach and Support, Dean on Call system, and Health Educators, plus student MedLinks and EMTs, will be available to answer your questions. Drop in anytime during this hour, which precedes the President's Welcome and Featured Faculty Speakers.

column5: Student Center, 2nd Floor, La Sala de Puerto Rico
column6: See first-hand the accessible and cutting edge research opportunities available to MIT undergraduates! A complete list of Friday's UROP tour descriptions will be available. Tour sign-up required to participate. Note: Sign up for Friday tours begins on Thursday at 4pm and may not extend far into Friday morning due to limited availability. Limit one tour per student. For general information about the UROP program, come to the UROP discussion panel, Friday at 1pm in Room 26-100.
Come start your day right with breakfast at Burton Conner!

column5: Student Center, 2nd Floor, La Sala de Puerto Rico
column6: Grab a cup of coffee or tea and chat with current MIT parents as well as parents of other MIT prefrosh. Also, learn about the MIT Parents Association and the Parent Connector Network from current volunteers and staff.

For general questions regarding our financial aid program, loans, student employment, and billing, please visit the Student Services Center in 11-120. Staff will also be available to answer individual questions about your financial aid application or award.

President L. Rafael Reif welcomes you to CPW and introduces featured MIT faculty speakers Professor Kristala Jones Prather, Theodore T. Miller Associate Professor of Chemical Engineering, Professor Pattie Maes, Alexander W. Dreyfoos (1954) Professor in Media Arts and Sciences, and Professor William Broadhead, Associate Professor of History and MacVicar Faculty Fellow.

column4: BBQ and Sports with the ZBT
column6: Grab a burger or a sandwich and play soccer, ultimate frisbee, and other sports with the brothers of ZBT.
Take a break from classes and come by for a bite or two prepared by our very own Chef John. We're located conveniently on dorm row.

We'll be rolling a giant brightly colored ball around campus collecting signatures in support of Children's Miracle Network! Come sign our ball and show your support - each signature earns us a donation from our sponsors!
Come visit Terrascope, a community in which students take charge of their own learning experience as they develop the skill to work in teams on complex, interdisciplinary research.

Join us for lunch and meet some amazing young women! Be inspired by stories of their MIT experience, hear how they became leaders in our community and get useful advice for success in college. The first 50 admitted women to attend will receive a special gift!
Come enjoy some free lunch by making your own pizza with delectable toppings. You should probably eat said pizza as well.

column4: Mad Hatter Tea and Brunch at Senior House
column6: Enter the magical world of mystery by donning a bizarre hat and drinking tasty tea in Senior Haus! Brunch will happen as the clock ticks and the rabbit jumps. Crumpets, scones, Earl Grey, eggs, and wonder.

The Department of Architecture welcomes prefrosh and parents to a presentation by the Head of the Department and the Undergraduate Officer. Learn about the Bachelor of Science in Architecture. Join the student led tour of the Department following Q and A.

Come to the Global Education and Career Development Center and learn more about research, internships, public service projects and study abroad opportunities. Also, learn about distinguished fellowships such as the Fulbright, Rhodes, Marshall and more!

Come speak with Career Services staff about the wide variety of services and support we provide to students, such as finding a summer internship or a job after graduation, writing a resume, or applying to graduate school. Also learn about the Freshman/Alumni Summer Internship Program (F/ASIP)!
Come to the Global Education and Career Development Center and meet with staff members to discuss services offered for premed and prehealth students.

column4: Brain and Cognitive Sciences Lab Tours and Pizz
column6: View our MRI facility, see our undergrad wet lab and have some pizza with BCS. Closed toed shoes and pants required.

The staff of the Office of Minority Education (OME), along with past Interphase participants, will discuss the benefits of participating in the 2013 Interphase EDGE program. (This event also occurs on Thursday from 4pm to 5:30pm in Room 10-250.)
Served steaming cold.

column4: Leading  Jewish Minds, Featuring David Kaiser
column6: Launched in 2009 as an on-campus lunchtime seminar series for faculty, staff, alumni/ae, and friends, Leading Jewish Minds @ MIT is an initiative to build and strengthen MIT's Jewish community. Kosher lunch provided, complementary.
Drop by for some refreshments and a quick bite between classes and CPW.
Come hang out with current Jewish students over kosher pizza and games! Find out about kosher dining and Hillel's various programs throughout the year.

column4: Sloan Business Club Meet and Greet
column6: Interested in business? Want to learn about the opportunities that MIT has to offer? Meet the members of SBC and learn how to get involved with the business world at MIT.

column4: Chilling n Grilling with Phi Delta Theta
column6: Hungry? Feel like hanging out? Come join Phi Delts outside the Student Center for some good food and pick up soccer to take a break from the day of activities.

Come get to know more about the Latino group LUChA while eating a tasty snack! We will be handing out fresh elote (corn with toppings) outside the Student Center. We will be here until all of it is gone!

column4: MIT Emerson Scholars Jazz Trio Concert
column6: Emerson Scholar Student Recital. Dylan Sherry (Graduate Student), saxophone, Peter Godart '15, piano, Adrian Grossman '14, electric bass.
Now that you're all grown up and going to college, fingerpainting just isn't enough anymore... come paint with your BODY! Smocks provided.

Parents and prefrosh are encouraged to attend a presentation on financing an MIT education. Included will be information about the online student account, a general overview of the undergraduate financial aid program, how to apply for loans, and how to find on-campus student employment. Elizabeth M. Hicks, Executive Director of Student Financial Services, will address these issues and more. (This session is also offered on Thursday at 1pm in Kresge Auditorium.)
Find out why pika has the coolest house in Cambridge  marvel at our talking pantry, give our chickens some company, and more.

Did you know MIT has more than one library? One is housed inside the Great Dome, another has great views of Boston, and they all have something special to offer. Take a fun and informative walking tour to learn where the Libraries are located and what they can do for you. We'll visit several libraries (as time allows) and give highlights of each library's collections, study spaces and services. Look for tour guides at the entrance to the library.

column4: Hair Dyeing, Grilling, and Painting the Berlin Wall
column6: It takes a special kind of person to pull off the full rainbow, but I can tell that you, sir/madame, are that kind of person. Remember: regret nothing! Come paint yourself and others. Grills are hot all day.
Departing on the hour and the half hour from Wiesner Student Art Gallery.
Come play soccer and eat some great Brazilian meats with the members of Society of Hispanic Professional Engineers (SHPE)-MIT.

column4: Tie Dye your own Maseeh T shirt
column6: Don't have enough free shirts? Join us in the Maseeh Courtyard to create your very own tie-dyed Maseeh shirt! Make sure to come early though before they're gone!

column4: Pizza on the Steps with Phi Sigma Kappa
column6: Stop by the Student Center steps for some hot pizza to fuel up for the day.
Departing on the hour and the half hour from Wiesner Student Art Gallery.
Stop by the MIT Energy Initiative (MITEI) to learn what MITEI is and does, talk to students involved in energy research and education, and discover how to get involved in campus energy projects.

column4: Grillin and Chillin at Sigma Chi
column6: Find yourself in Boston? Stop by Sigma Chi for some free food off the grill! We'll be grillin' and chillin' all afternoon.

In this lab, you're invited to watch a fun, interactive, hands-on exercise in which Gordon Engineering Leaders (GELs) hone their skills in: making effective use of available resources (team, materials, etc.) to solve an engineering problem, managing the use of time, responding to change by taking alternative courses of action, and listening to and supporting viewpoints different from their own.

column4: Next Gamers, MIT's REAL PE requirement
column6: We don't think your physical activities are up to MIT standards. We can fix that for you. Come play Ultimate Capture the Frozen King and Battleship Twister at the end of the sidewalk.

column4: Artsy and Crafty Tire-Swinging and BBQ at Senior House
column6: Learn how to tire-swing! This is no child's back-and-forth swing. We go MIT style: rotation, precession, gyration, elation. Once you've given enough blood to the tree, make some Sport Death-y crafts. Tons of food.
Come learn more about the Concourse Learning Community and the options available during your freshman year at MIT. Join our students and faculty for light refreshments.
Moon bounce! Bubbles! Moon bounce! Face paint! Moon bounce! Balloons! Did we mention there's a moon bounce?

Come learn about all aspects of UROP at MIT, including how to participate, what type of research is appropriate, what to expect from the program, and more. Discussion will center on the experiences of the UROP student panel as moderated by UROP staff. Plenty of time will be allowed for questions!

column4: Student Activities, Athletics and Leadership Panel
column6: There's more to life than just academics! Learn about the many ways students are engaged in campus activities that enhance areas of intellectual, personal, athletic, and social development. Chris Colombo, Dean for Student Life, campus administrators, and students will answer your questions.
Departing on the hour and the half hour from Wiesner Student Art Gallery.

A panel presentation and discussion featuring First Generation MIT students and faculty describing their experiences as the First Generation in their family to graduate from a four-year university. Students and families welcome!
It's like Assassins and Capture the Flag, but at the same time and with Nerf guns.

column4: Dunk the Admissions Committee with Amphibious Achievement
column6: The name says it all. Come join us on Kresge and get the chance to dunk all your favorite Admissions Officers and Bloggers! At the same time, learn about Amphibious Achievement and hang with passionate students who double as mentors and coaches for Boston high school students! Fro-yo will be provided, of course

Gather to bemoan the decline of our Queen Victoria's empire or gossip about the most recent painters at the Salon. Tea will be served, enjoyment will be had. There may be Downton or Emma: A Victorian Romance.
Departing on the hour and the half hour from Wiesner Student Art Gallery.
Play games on Kresge's and TDC's lawn! Bouncy House! Balloon darts! Face painting! Sumo wrestling! Dunk tanks! Waffles and Ice cream! If you collect the most tickets by 6PM you can win a GRAND PRIZE!

Prefrosh, welcome to the Institute! As the Interfraternity Council (IFC) of MIT, we sincerely hope that, as we did when we were first admitted ourselves, you choose MIT to be your home for the next four years. In your quest to get to know what life is like at the Institute, stop by and hear about how being fraternity men at MIT has enriched our lives and really contributed to make an already amazing experience an unforgettable one!

Join the MIT Chapter of NSBE for an Iron Chef throw down! Test your culinary skills with this friendly competition for all cooking levels. We'll be rolling out the mystery ingredient early on, so don't miss out!

Congratulations on your child's acceptance to MIT! Come meet the Executive Board of the Interfraternity Council (IFC) and the Directors of the Fraternities, Sororities, and Independent Living Groups Office, find out about fraternity life at MIT and ask any lingering questions you may have!

Undergraduate students and academic department/program representatives, as well as students, faculty, and staff from MIT's arts community will be on hand to provide information about the variety of majors and programs offered at MIT.

column4: Athletics, Physical Education and Recreation Fair
column6: Meet educators, coaches, and athletes, and learn all about the physical education, recreation, intramural, club and athletic programs and opportunities at MIT.

Check out entrepreneurship at MIT - from student clubs and competitions to startups and cool technology! Come hang out with our faculty and student entrepreneurs, get free stuff and refreshments, and learn how to get involved!

WE LIKE SPORTZ AND WE DON'T CARE WHO KNOWS. Toss me the Frisbee. Now throw me the football. Now kick me the soccer ball! There might even be water balloons... Meet at the Steps and then we'll head over to Brigg's Field C (between New House, W70 and Simmons, W79).

Interested in how MIT helps get you amazing careers and job offers? Come talk to the brothers of Phi Beta Epsilon! They will be talking about their career paths throughout their years at MIT and answering any questions that you have. Lunch will be served.
Explore the Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Lab (CSAIL), see robotics demonstrations and hear from students and faculty about all of the exciting research underway here!

What happens when you mix smoothies and origami? You get'wet sticky paper. Luckily, we're not doing that. We have state of the art cups that are specifically designed to keep smoothies out of your origami.
Departing on the hour and the half hour from Wiesner Student Art Gallery.

Drop by DKE for a light afternoon snack and get to know your future classmates at a rooftop social overlooking Boston from the edge of the Charles River. We will be making custom smoothies to order and playing rooftop games.
Join the MIT Muslim Student Association (MSA) on a scavenger hunt of epic proportions! Gather clues and race to the end while getting to know the MIT campus!

Race all over Maseeh to discover all the fun things you do in MIT's newest dorm. Don't spend too long at any one place though because the fastest person gets a grand prize! (You can always go back though!)
Uhh... I meant vegetarian cooking. Yeah. Come tuck into a meat-free feast prepared for you by Randomites. If you eat vegans--vegan! I meant vegan!--there will be plenty of options available.
Departing on the hour and the half hour from Wiesner Student Art Gallery.
Bubble tea, bubble smoothies, and fruit smoothies put on by MIT'S Tapioca Club! Grab a drink and stay for a Sloth Off and other zany activities!

Ever wondered what it is like to be a minority in a top-tier university? Well, we have the answers. Join the Brothers of Chocolate City as we discuss the experience of being a minority student at MIT.

Did you know that the first frisbee was a pie tin? Did you know the first game of Ultimate was played in a parking lot? Come learn more about Ultimate (including awesome tips on throwing!) and join the MIT Women's Ultimate Frisbee team for Frisbee-related games. Pie and prizes [read 'giveaways'] will be provided.
Departing on the hour and the half hour from Wiesner Student Art Gallery.

Check out MIT's only intentionally humorous publication - 'Voo Doo'! Give your poor digestive tract a break and FEED YOUR MIND instead. Make a Voo Doo doll, peruse our archives, or draw a comic in the company of our sharp-witted staff.

Come play dodgeball with Lambda Chi Alpha! Join us in the Z-center MAC court for a fun break from classes and competition against fellow pre-frosh and students. Dodge, duck, dip, dive and dodge until you are the last one standing.

Tour the Rainbow Lounge with burritos, pinatas, salsa dancing, and lots of great people...what a great way to spend a Friday afternoon! Please join us to celebrate and welcome new MIT pre-frosh into the LBGT and LBGT-Ally community at MIT.
Come enjoy music from the Caribbean with a steel pan band performance. You can just listen or dance along to music, but it's guaranteed to be a good time.
Come play Quidditch -- the magical sport from Harry Potter -- with MIT's Quidditch Team, the MIT Marauders! Brooms provided. No flying experience necessary. Butterbeer (non-alcoholic) will be served.

Do you like to dance? Do you like put a beat down on your favorite childhood characters? Do you like food? If you answered 'YES' to any of these questions then Burton Conner is the place for you. Come on over to get your warm-up for the night's parties, get that nostalgia flowing, and of course, get some free food.
Everything is bigger in Sims. Giant ball pits. Giant Jenga. Giant origami. Giant twister. Famangomadan.

Learn about the many kinds of interactions that occur between students and faculty at MIT, and the wonderful collaborative environment in which they work and study together. Bring your questions about academic support, advising and guidance. Daniel Hastings, Dean of Undergraduate Education, will be joined by administrators and current students to address questions.

column6: Students compare notes from their Media Lab UROP projects and learn how to present research results.

MIT is the place for students dreaming of turning great ideas into successful businesses - and some have been phenomenal successes. Hear students who've launched ventures while on campus and meet leaders of our Entrepreneurial Ecosystem network, that supports and encourages aspiring entrepreneurs.

Learn about Air Force ROTC and meet current students developing as young leaders while pursuing a variety of careers including flying, engineering, and intelligence. We'll be serving snacks and hosting a glider-flying competition'come test your design skills!

column6: Come to pika's TV room and say hello to the Doctor (among other classic sci-fi characters)!

Compete with Bakerites in a friendly game of Dodgeball. From awesome GRTs to lively residents, find out what our community has to offer.

column4: Saving the World Step 2, doing something
column6: Prototyping and testing innovative solutions to problems around the world with the members of iHouse!!!!!
Meet the Experimental Study Group (ESG) staff and find out more about how ESG's small, interactive classes are taught. Refreshments served.

column4: Make and Eat all the pies
column6: Come make some delicious pies (pecan, blueberry, strawberry-rhubarb, chocolate, apple, or whatever deliciousness you can imagine!) and talk about cooking and eating at MIT with some of the amateur chefs of Burton Conner.

Join the Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering for an open house and information session led by Course 1 students. Explore how we are solving some of the world's most pressing problems and engineering a sustainable future!

column4: Department of Materials Science and Engineering Open House
column6: Please join the Department of Materials Science and Engineering for an Open House. Information regarding the undergraduate program in DMSE will be discussed with a question and answer session. Light refreshments will be served.

Interested in International Development, but don't know where to begin? Come check out this informative panel of student groups and professors who will discuss the numerous ways you can integrate international development into your academics and extracurricular activities while here at MIT.

column4: Solar electric vehicle team shop tour
column6: We build vehicles to go 60 mph on the power of a hairdryer - come see how and where we do it.

Eat FREE PASTRIES from the famous Modern Pastries and hear us share tiny TIMTalks -- personal stories of innovation and insomnia, success amidst failure, and passion under pressure. This is drinking from the firehose -- this is the real MIT. INCREDIBLE CANNOLIS.Sponsored by the Public Service Center (PSC).
An information session about TechCASH, which allows students to access their meal plans and free campus printing quota, as well as purchase food, meals, books, and more using their MIT ID Card.
This 30-minute info session on Mechanical Engineering (Course 2) will be conducted by Professor Derek Rowell. A Teaching Lab tour will be available immediately following the information session.

Curious about the exciting sport of rugby? Interested in playing rugby in the fall? Come to Brigg's Field and learn some basic rugby skills and meet the team. No prior rugby or sports experience necessary. They'll be free snacks.
Stop by and see our recently renovated rec room for an old-fashioned pool tournament.

What is the longest hallway on the MIT campus? What are the first 10 digits of pi? What was Harry Potter's wand made out of? Come show off your knowledge! There will be multiple rounds so stop by whenever.

column5: Alpha Epsilon Pi (155 Bay State Rd)
column6: Come play a friendly game of ultimate frisbee with the Brothers of Alpha Epsilon Pi! We will be playing on the banks of the Charles River, right in our backyard! Meet up at our house and we'll head over together.
Come learn more about The Leadership Training institute and the awesome things we do! Enjoy pizza and games, meet some of our awesome mentors and exec members, and learn why LTI is so special.
Feeling hungry on your first day of CPW? We can fix that with some fine surf & turf! Come join the brothers of Theta Chi for some juicy, sizzling steaks.

Graduate student Eleanor Bors, cellist, performs: Faure, Sonata for violon, cello and piano in D Minor, Op. 109, Crumb, Sonata for violoncello, and Beethoven, Sonata for Violoncello and piano in C Major, Op. 102, No. 1.
Come grab dumplings with the Asian American Association (AAA) before heading off to your Friday night festivities!

Didn't get LN2 ice cream at the kickoff? Or did that one taste leave you craving more? Either way, come to EC for some of that legendarily smooth liquid nitrogen ice cream at one of our Friday Afternoon Clubs.
Meet with faculty, staff and students to learn about our undergraduate curriculum and current research projects.
Sponsored by the MIT Parents Association and the MIT Club of Boston, this reception is your chance to meet and mingle with Parent Connectors, Educational Counselors and other MIT Alumni.

The Black, Latino, and Native American students at the Institute would like to invite prefrosh for an ice cream social. Ask current students questions and meet future classmates over ice cream and froyo.Sponsored by the Association of Puerto Rican Students.

Join the Ladies of the Black Women's Alliance (BWA) as we indulge in a little decadence. What's a girl without her favorite jewels and most beautiful gems? We will be making jewelry while enjoying delicious desserts, so come show off your creativity and eye for beauty while engaging in conversation with minority women on campus.
Ever wondered how you would look with a tattoo? We'll help you test drive one! White shirt too boring? No problem! Get covered in tattoos and tie dye at the Haus!
Come help ET's wonderful alums combine dough, onions, mushrooms, pineapples, and other things to make something vaguely resembling pizza! Meet us in Lobby 7 to take our van to ET.

column4: Nerdy Sing Along and Kit Kat Lasagna
column6: Go ahead and leave me - I think I prefer to stay inside. Sing along to our favorite nerdy songs, and then make lasagna entirely out of candy. Hopefully we'll be still alive.
Our capsaicin-infused ice cream doesn't know what temperature to be. Put it out of its sad, confused misery with science.
Come by and chow down on some delicious and savory meats grilled to perfection by our very own Chef John. Don't worry, we have vegetarian options, too.
Enjoy some delicious burgers and hot dogs at the BBQ pits by Kresge. Too full? Then work it off playing frisbee and soccer with the PiLam brothers.
Come, hang out and enjoy delicious Pho (including beef, chicken and vegetarian options catered from local restaurant!). Event sponsored by Vietnamese Student Association.

Come join LuChA (La Union Chicana Por Aztlan) for an AWESOME game night in the basement of the Student Center! Loteria is a Latin-American game of picture bingo, we will have a ton of other games, yummy Latino NOMS and dancing too!

column4: Society Of Women engineers Informational Dinner
column6: Join the Society of Women Engineers (SWE) and Undergraduate Society of Women in Mathematics (USWIM) to learn about MIT's most active undergraduate women's groups. Meet MIT's female STEM community, find out how to become involved and enjoy a delicious Thai catered dinner!
Chow down on a thick juicy steak and tender baby back ribs.
The Student Information Processing Board (SIPB) runs a lot of cool services for MIT, and we keep our secure hardware separate from the main office. Come get a tour of our machine room!
The Association of Puerto Rican Students (APR) invites you to their annual CPW dinner! Join us if you're interested in learning more about our group or Puerto Rico.
D'nez au restaurant fran'ais! Come experience the finest dining west of Mass Ave. Cooking starts at 4pm if you fancy yourself a chef (no cooking experience or French actually required). Bon app_tit!
Come on over for a home cooked meal with the brothers of ZBT. Tonight our chef is making her delicious flank steak. A vegetarian option will also be available. Call Rick for Rides (617-232-3257).
How much can you eat? Test your limits. Win a prize, if you have what it takes.

Come and challenge our most deadly Super Smash Brothers player, Roosevelt Fitzgerald Boyland III (aka Trey) in mortal combat. Fight to the death, win eternal glory, or just watch and eat food. Cards Against Humanity, Settlers of Catan, and Oregon Trail will also be provided.

Come to Phi Kappa Sigma (Skullhouse) for chef extraordinaire Gerry Martinez's delicious fried chicken, with corn and mashed potatoes. You haven't tried chicken until you've tried Gerry's fried chicken.
Come chill and share some delicious crepes and coffee with the Brothers and Sisters of No6.

column4: Everything Awesome All the Time Always
